question: The module explains the 3 characteristics of Big Data, namely Variety, Velocity and Volume. Name and explain the other 2Vs that have been explained in the module.
ground_truth: The other two Vs are: 1. Veracity: Refers to the quality and accuracy of data. In large data sets, there is often incomplete, inaccurate, or irrelevant data, which can disrupt the analysis process if not handled properly. 2. Value: Refers to the value or information that can be obtained from Big Data processing. Having large volumes of data with high velocity, variety, and veracity is useless without the ability to convert it into business value or useful knowledge.
answer: Two other characteristics of 2V in Big Data are Veracity and Value. The character of veracity and validity refers to how accurate and trustworthy the quality or credibility of the data obtained is. This is because big data has vulnerabilities in terms of accuracy and level of data validity, so it requires more depth to analyze big data in order to produce the right output. Value refers to how valuable or meaningful the existing data is. Big data has very high value if processed in the right way. Value is how feasible the data is to have a positive impact on the company's business. We can carry out further analysis regarding the value of the data obtained. Data that has no value in any part will not be filtered in the Big Data analysis application system.

question: Give examples of Big Data implementation in your respective fields
ground_truth: Here are some examples of Big Data implementation in various fields: 1. Social Media Sentiment Analysis: Companies can use Big Data to analyze sentiment on social media towards their brand, product or service. By monitoring millions of tweets, Facebook posts, and other online reviews, they can understand customer views in real-time, identify trends, and respond quickly to changing perceptions or emerging issues. 2. Health Data Processing: In the health sector, Big Data is used to analyze clinical, genomic and other patient data to discover patterns, trends, and associations that can assist in disease diagnosis, drug development, and more effective and personalized treatment planning. 3. Supply Chain Optimization: Companies operating in the manufacturing or retail industry use Big Data to optimize their supply chains. By analyzing data related to customer demand, inventory, and production processes, they can identify areas where efficiency can be improved, reduce costs, and increase customer satisfaction by ensuring the right product is available at the right time.

answer: I come from a health nutrition study program, so the field I study is of course related to food, consumption, and health. One of the things that must be fulfilled and is a crucial component in people's diet is related to food safety. WHO recently used a Big Data approach to support decision-making in food safety resulting in the food safety platform FOSCOLLAB, to provide integration of various scientific disciplines. In this platform, structured and unstructured data from various sectors such as animal, agricultural, food, public health and economic indicators are integrated and made available to users through several dedicated dashboards. Data sources connected to FOSCOLLAB are Evaluations from the Joint FAO WHO Expert Committee on Food Additives JECFA and The Joint FAO WHO Meeting on Pesticide Residues JMPR data base regarding chemical risk assessment, the WHO database at the Collaborating Center and GEMS food regarding food consumption and chemical content in food. Information from additional data will be integrated as the FOSCOLLAB platform develops, which will support actors operating in food and feed risk analysis, for example in analyzing the risk of contamination or contamination contained in a food ingredient.

answer: In the field of nutrition, one of the databases needed is a database regarding the food consumed by clients. This food-related database is usually found in an application for laptops called nutrisurvey. However, the food database in the application is not complete so an input process is required for types of food that are not in the database or foods that have different composition variations in the database. This becomes very troublesome because the input process is only carried out on one nutrisurvey application on one laptop computer. So, when a nutritionist wants to replace a device, or for example, in conditions where it is not possible to bring his or her device, this input process must be done from the start again. Therefore, Big Data can be implemented. The Big Data created is related to food and its composition and caloric value which can later be accessed and edited by all nutrition experts in Indonesia, so that later its use will be easier.

question: Give examples of Big Data implementation in your respective fields
ground_truth: Here are some examples of Big Data implementation in various fields: 1. Social Media Sentiment Analysis: Companies can use Big Data to analyze sentiment on social media towards their brand, product or service. By monitoring millions of tweets, Facebook posts, and other online reviews, they can understand customer views in real-time, identify trends, and respond quickly to changing perceptions or emerging issues. 2. Health Data Processing: In the health sector, Big Data is used to analyze clinical, genomic and other patient data to discover patterns, trends, and associations that can assist in disease diagnosis, drug development, and more effective and personalized treatment planning. 3. Supply Chain Optimization: Companies operating in the manufacturing or retail industry use Big Data to optimize their supply chains. By analyzing data related to customer demand, inventory, and production processes, they can identify areas where efficiency can be improved, reduce costs, and increase customer satisfaction by ensuring the right product is available at the right time.
answer: - Social media Big data on social media can be used to analyze election or regional election wins in an area. Sentiment analysis can be used to determine public sentiment, especially Twitter and Facebook netizens, towards a candidate in an election or regional election. The aim is to help people determine the sentiment contained in comments on social media Twitter and Facebook. The first step that must be taken is to collect the necessary data, namely comments from people who use social media regarding candidates in elections or regional elections. Sources of research data can come from social media Twitter and Facebook. Next, the text preprocessing stage will be carried out. For text obtained from public comments, a process of sentence selection, sentence cleaning, sentence stemming and sentence normalization will be carried out. After the text has been processed and has become clean text, it will proceed to the classification process stage. In the classification process, the Nave Bayes Classifier method can be used to determine the sentiment of an opinion sentence. The final stage is to evaluate the performance of Accuracy, Precision, Recall and Error using the Confusion Matrix method. - Marketing a. Telecommunications companies leverage big data analysis to prevent customer churn. Apart from that, big data is also used to plan the best way to optimize both new and existing wireless networks so that product marketing can run smoothly. b. Marketing uses big data to carry out sentiment analysis to determine the level of customer satisfaction with the products and services being marketed, so that more effective marketing tricks can be designed and attract the interest of many customers. c. Retail companies can use information from social media such as Facebook, Twitter, Google which is stored using big data technology, which is then used to analyze customer behavior and perceptions of a company's product or brand. - Education Data analysis through big data allows teachers or consultants to provide advice on very specific career directions to students. A startup in Santa Monica, 12Twenty offers solutions in service management or career information centers for educational institutions, students, and entrepreneurs. 12Twenty also provides a range of products such as a career recommendation platform, more effective management of employment processes, giving students a better understanding of the hiring cycle, and helping employers find candidates according to their desires and expectations. Apart from that, 12Twenty uses big data to give students access to salary information and a list of interview questions through a database so that after graduation students can prepare optimally when there is an interview call. - Corporate Health can conduct clinical trials, using Big Data and predictive analysis. Patients selected for this test may meet certain prerequisites found through several databases, and researchers can monitor clinical trial participants in real-time. Big Data also has the ability to predict the side effects of certain compounds before clinical trials are conducted. Currently, methods for predicting drug toxicity levels

answer: Pharmacies are faced with managing a large supply of medical supplies. If it is not supported by adequate systems and data, it will make it difficult to manage existing inventory. Therefore, it is important to utilize data through a good system. Leveraging data will provide extensive opportunities for pharmacies to reduce costs and optimize cash flow, as well as improve operational efficiency and patient outcomes. The abundance of data and lack of powerful computational analysis technologies are the biggest barriers to data use in pharma. Pharmacies need to collect data on the number of prescriptions, drug redemptions, purchase frequency, and many other aspects. The ability to translate these massive data sets into useful information is called Big Data. Big data is able to collect data into valuable information. This includes displaying drug analytics and statistics that allow the head of pharmacy to quickly and efficiently see areas that require attention. With Big Data, all patient health information and medication management becomes centralized so that it is easy to process and analyze to find out details about what therapy is most appropriate for the patient to use.

answer: 1. UNITEDHEALTHCARE: FRAUD, WASTE, AND ABUSE Currently at least 10 of Health insurance payments are related to fraudulent claims. Worldwide this case is estimated to be worth billions of dollars. False claims are not a new problem, but the complexity of insurance fraud appears to be increasing exponentially making it difficult for health insurance companies to deal with it. UnitedHealthCare is an insurance company that provides health benefits and services to nearly 51 million people. This company collaborates with more than 850,000 health workers and around 6,100 hospitals throughout the country. Payment Integrity group's payment integrity division has a duty to ensure that claims are paid correctly and on time. Previously, their approach to managing more than one million claims per day, around 10 TB of data per day, was ad hoc, heavily regulated, and hampered by fragmented data. The solution taken by UnitedHealthCare is a dual mode approach, which focuses on allocating savings while implementing innovation to continue to utilize the latest technology. 2. HADOOP TECHNOLOGY FOR MONITORING THE VITAL CONDITION OF PATIENTS Hadoop is a Java-based open source framework or platform under the Apache license to support applications that run on Big Data. Several hospitals around the world have used Hadoop to help their staff work efficiently with Big Data. Without Hadoop, it would be nearly impossible for most healthcare systems to analyze unstructured data. Children's Healthcare of Atlanta uses sensors at the patient's bedside to track the patient's vital conditions such as heart rate, breathing and blood pressure. This sensor can produce very large amounts of data and the system is not able to process this data because storing the data requires large amounts of storage and the costs are large. even though this hospital needs to store vital data for analysis. If there is a change in pattern, there needs to be notification to the team of doctors and staff. 3. VALENCE HEALTH: IMPROVING SERVICE QUALITY AND REIMBURSEMENTS Valence health uses Hadoop to build a data lake which is the main storage of company data. Valence processes 3000 inbound data feeds with 45 types of data every day. This critical data includes lab test results, medical record data, doctor's prescriptions, immunizations, medications, claims and payments, as well as claims from doctors and hospitals, which are used to inform decisions to increase both income and reimbursement. The rapid growth in the number of clients and the associated increase in data volumes increasingly strain existing infrastructure

Industrial sector: - To avoid high costs associated with supply chain failures, a company will look for better ways to manage the delivery of raw materials. The industry will decide to use detailed supplier route data, as well as weather and traffic data provided by reliable external sources, to identify possible delivery delays. Using Big Data, they carry out predictive analysis and calculate possible delays and shortages of raw materials. Based on these calculations, companies can make contingency plans regarding inventory and now they can run their production without interruption and of course avoid excessive downtime costs.

Social Media Sentiment Analysis: Companies can use Big Data to analyze sentiment on social media towards their brand, product or service. By monitoring millions of tweets, Facebook posts, and other online reviews, they can understand customer views in real-time, identify trends, and respond quickly to changing perceptions or emerging issues. 2. Health Data Processing: In the health sector, Big Data is used to analyze clinical, genomic and other patient data to discover patterns, trends, and associations that can assist in disease diagnosis, drug development, and more effective and personalized treatment planning. 3. Supply Chain Optimization: Companies operating in the manufacturing or retail industry use Big Data to optimize their supply chains. By analyzing data related to customer demand, inventory, and production processes, they can identify areas where efficiency can be improved, reduce costs, and increase customer satisfaction by ensuring the right product is available at the right time.
answer: In the field of securities or stock markets and finance there is a lot of data and it even changes every hour. The data in the stock market can be classified as Big Data. Where big data analysis on the stock market is very necessary to monitor financial markets through network activity monitors and language processors to reduce fraud in transactions.

answer: Pharmacies need to collect data on the number of prescriptions, drug redemptions, frequency of purchases, and so on. In the pharmaceutical sector, an example of the application of big data is that the pharmaceutical company Kimia Farma launched the Kimia Farma Mobile application which has been connected and integrated with more than 1,300 Kimia Farma pharmacies throughout Indonesia. This application is equipped with big data analytic technology to facilitate the inventory, control and monitoring process from the center to each outlet from the sales side. Apart from that, it is also useful for making it easier to find medicines at the pharmacy. The data can be used to track drug shortages and the reasons why they occur. The use of data can help pharmaceutical departments manage the reverse distribution process by tracking when drug supplies will run out based on buyer habits. Data can also minimize excess inventory by providing the frequency with which unpopular medications are used. Data helps pharmacists improve operational efficiency and costs. Inventory control is a critical part of a pharmacy's ability to manage patient care and maintain profitability. Data allows for more accurate inventory tracking, so supply disruptions do not occur and pharmacists can take advantage of bulk purchases and special price offers. Through data availability, Big Data can drive treatment adherence and better patient outcomes. Using data, pharmacists can make treatment recommendations based on elements such as diet, supplements, drug education and medication adherence.

answer: 1. Patients can avoid waiting in queues and doctors can save time in consultations and filling in patient documents. question: Mention and briefly explain the characteristics of a data collection called Big Data
ground_truth: The characteristics of a data collection called Big Data are often summarized by the "5Vs": 1. Volume: Refers to the enormous amount of data generated every day. 2. Velocity: Indicates the rate at which new data is generated and how quickly it needs to be processed. 3. Variety: Describes the different types and sources of data available, including structured, unstructured, and semi-structured data. 4. Veracity: Relates to the quality and accuracy of data. 5. Value: Refers to the value or information that can be obtained from Big Data processing. These characteristics highlight the scale, complexity, and diversity of Big Data, which require specialized processing and analysis techniques to extract valuable insights.
answer: Data is called Big Data when the amount of data is so large, fast or complex that it is difficult or impossible to process using traditional methods.

Velocity: Indicates the rate at which new data is generated and how quickly it needs to be processed. 3. Variety: Describes the different types and sources of data available, including structured, unstructured, and semi-structured data. 4. Veracity: Relates to the quality and accuracy of data. 5. Value: Refers to the value or information that can be obtained from Big Data processing. These characteristics highlight the scale, complexity, and diversity of Big Data, which require specialized processing and analysis techniques to extract valuable insights.
answer: Big data is very large in size, varied, has a fast growth rate, and can be structured or not. Big data is data that is difficult to collect, store or manage with traditional database systems because its volume continues to increase.

answer: In simple terms, a data set to be called Big Data has the following characteristics, namely: The data contained in the data set is very large and continues to grow exponentially over time. The large amount of data means that the data collection cannot be processed and analyzed using conventional data processing methods. If data mining, data storage, data analysis, data sharing, and data visualization are used to collect large amounts of data, it is necessary to apply Big Data concepts because the amount is very large. If explained further, several characteristics of a collection of data called Big Data are: Volume means that data can be categorized into Big Data if it has a large size or it is possible that it can grow very quickly so that it requires very large storage. Variety means that data can be called Big Data if it has various characteristics and is not homogeneous, but has many variables and is very diverse, including various types of data, both data that has been structured in a database and data that is not organized in a database. Velocity means Big Data has the characteristic of changing very quickly both in terms of variables and data types. With these characteristics, a special touch is needed in processing Big Data. Veracity means Big Data has vulnerabilities in terms of accuracy and validity so it requires depth to analyze Big Data in order to produce the right decisions. Value means that Big Data has very high value if it is processed in an appropriate way. Thus, it is clear that Big Data is not only about very large sizes but also has characteristics such as very diverse types of data and very high rates of growth and frequency of change.

answer: According to Baaziz and Quoniam 2015, the first 3 characteristics of Big Data were developed by the Meta Group which include 3V: Volume, Velocity, and Variety. Based on data quality, IBM added a fourth characteristic called Veracity. Then, Oracle added a fifth characteristic called Value, so that in the end Big Data has 5 characteristics. According to Zhang, et al. 2017, the characteristics of big data are 5V with the following explanation. VOLUME records very large amounts of data resulting in very large amounts of information as well as VELOCITY data processed and produced at high speed VARIETY various kinds of structured, semi-structured and unstructured data that cannot be stored in ordinary databases VALUE extraction of data values accurate and economical requires sophisticated data solutions VERACITY truth can make data analysis more accurate, so that data quality can be improved

question: What are the 3 differences between a relational database and a data warehouse?
ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: 1. Relational Database The Relational Database Model presents data in two-dimensional tables, like a spreadsheet, only it is not presented in a table like a spreadsheet but uses a combination or joining of relational tables to produce a view or display results. 2. Data Warehouse Data Warehouse Model, also known as enterprise data warehouse is a system used for data reporting and analysis and is considered a core component of business intelligence.

Data warehouse: Data warehouse organizes and processes large amounts of historical data and provides several facilities. Data warehouses also deal with various information obtained from several other organizations, which combine from various data storage places. This will cause very large volumes so that warehouse data is stored in several storage areas. The access pattern in the data warehouse is mostly read only. This is because most of the data stored is historical data and only a little new data.

question: What are the 3 differences between a relational database and a data warehouse?
ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: The differences between relational databases and data warehouses are: Relational databases are used in OLTP Online Processing Transactions and can be used for data warehouse needs, and are customer oriented and used in query and transaction processes. The data warehouse is used in Online Analytical Processing OLAP which is capable of reading historical data for users in the decision making process, as well as being market oriented and used in the data analysis process by people who have professional knowledge fields.

question: What are the 3 differences between a relational database and a data warehouse?
ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN A RELATION DATABASE AND DATA WAREHOUSE A relation database is a collection of data in the form of files, archives or tables which are arranged in such a way according to certain rules, connected to each other and stored in electronic media where it is easy for users to manage them and easy to obtain information. A data warehouse is a collection of data originating from various sources stored in a large capacity data warehouse that is used in the decision making process. The difference between database vs data warehouse is explained in detail below: Databases are used in Transactional Online Processing OLTP and can also be used for data warehouse needs Data warehouses are used in Online Analytical Processing OLAP which is able to read historical data for users in the decision making process Tables and combinations in the database very complex so it can reduce redundant data and save storage space. Tables and joins in the data warehouse are relatively simple to reduce response times and analytical requests. The database is customer oriented and is used in query and transaction processes, for example by cashiers, sales assistants and IT professionals. Data warehouses are market oriented and are used in the data analysis process by people who have professional knowledge of the field, for example executives, managers and data analyst experts. Databases organize and process data in detail so that it is easy to use in the decision making process. The data warehouse organizes and processes large amounts of historical data and provides several facilities for calculating total sales and combining sales in each area, each month, and so on. Data warehouses store and process data according to different levels of granularity. Database systems generally adopt data entity relationship modeling and application-oriented design. Data warehouse systems generally adopt snowflake or star modeling and subject-oriented design. Databases focus on real time data in an organization or agency without referring to historical data or data from other organizations. Data warehouses often span various types of database schemas due to the evolutionary process of an organization. Data warehouses also deal with various information obtained from several other organizations, which combine from various data storage places. This will cause very large volumes so that warehouse data is stored in several storage areas. Access patterns in databases mainly consist of short atomic transactions and systems like this require concurency control and recovery mechanisms. The access pattern in the data warehouse is mostly read only. This is because most of the data stored is historical data and only a little new data.

answer: A relational database is a collection of data items with predefined relationships. These various items are organized into a set of tables with columns and rows. Tables are used to store information about objects that will be represented in the database. Each column in a table contains a specific type of data and fields store the actual values ​​of attributes. Rows in a table represent a collection of related values ​​from a single object or entity. Each row in a table can be tagged with a unique identifier called a primary key, and rows between multiple tables can be made related to each other using foreign keys. This data can be accessed in various ways without reordering the database tables themselves. In the relational model there is a term that has an important role in designing this type of database, this term is called Relational key. A relational key is one or a combination of several attributes that can uniquely distinguish all rows of data in a table. These types of relational keys include Superkey, Candidate Key, Primary Key Foreign Key and Composite Key. Meanwhile, a data warehouse is a collection of data originating from various sources that is stored in a large capacity data warehouse that is used in the decision making process. The data warehouse is used in Online Analytical Processing OLAP which is able to read historical data for users in the decision making process. The data warehouse organizes and processes large amounts of historical data and provides several facilities for calculating total sales and combining sales in each area, each month, and so on. Data warehouses store and process data according to different levels of granularity. Data warehouse systems generally adopt snowflake or star modeling and subject-oriented design. Data warehouses often span various types of database schemas due to the evolutionary process of an organization. Data warehouses also deal with various information obtained from several other organizations, which combine from various data storage places. This will cause very large volumes so that warehouse data is stored in several storage areas.

question: What are the 3 differences between a relational database and a data warehouse?
ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: A warehouse is a broad scope of storage and processing from various data sources, not only relational databases, which are integrated and easy to display information in drilldown or rollup. The commonly used relational database is the OLTP online transaction process area. Meanwhile, the data warehouse is the second stage, where data is no longer queried in large quantities and normalized, but the data has been aggregated according to the needs of the analysis report and has been normalized.

question: What challenges exist when implementing Big Data?
ground_truth: When implementing Big Data, the following challenges exist: 1. Data Management and Storage 2. Data Processing and Analysis 3. Data Quality and Cleanliness 4. Data Security and Privacy 5. Data Integration 6. Skills Shortage 7. Infrastructure and Operational Costs 8. Scalability 9. Business Understanding 10. Regulations and Compliance
answer: Big Data technology is a relatively new and developing technology. Currently, the focus of Big Data development is still focused on analysis capacity and data storage because these two things are the most important factors in determining the level of effectiveness and success of the Big Data system. This has an impact on the lack of energy and capital used to develop data security, resulting in various cases of data breaches and information theft. Currently, hackers and Big Data security continue to be developed continuously to ensure that systems that use Big Data are safe from data breaches or other forms of information theft and of course this requires quite frequent design changes or code updates. Even though this process takes a lot of time and energy. In addition, along with the times and innovations in the implementation of new technology, the types of data become increasingly diverse, the size of available data will grow exponentially. Moreover, considering that big data management is much different from conventional relational databases, sorting the desired data from the incoming data set is quite difficult. Data Availability One of the keys to conducting Big Data analysis is of course data availability. Access to data, both old data and new data, can be an obstacle for Big Data, especially old data which is stored in different and varied forms, often in physical form. Access to new data also requires more effort because permits and licenses are required to legally access non-public data. Especially if there is sectoral ego between agencies as data owners. This is what service and information providers who implement Big Data analytics in Indonesia feel, that the data collection phase is the main challenge. In fact, in Indonesia, data for various types of needs is available and abundant, but the sources are scattered, so more effort is needed to obtain integrated data nationally. Data Privacy On the one hand, data transparency is needed, but on the other hand, privacy is a sensitive issue and is often compromised through technological advances. Privacy relates to a person's personal data that must be protected. Much of the data used as Big Data, which is obtained directly from consumers, is personal data and is very vulnerable to misuse by other parties. When just one data requires guaranteed security, then when there is integration of data from several sources, the level of security must be further increased. Because the data stored is not small, but is related to many things. Technology This is related to infrastructure and tools in Big Data operations, such as computing and analytical techniques, as well as storage media. It cannot be denied that when you want to utilize Big Data technology, you must also be prepared with the technology, such as infrastructure and tools. Human Resources In applying Big Data technology, human resources are needed with analytical skills and creativity, namely the ability to determine new methods that can be used to collect, interpret and analyze data, computer programming skills, and business skills, namely an understanding of business goals.

Supporting infrastructure. answer: 1. Data from various sources is stored on different platforms. This can also be called velocity, which refers to the speed of growth or increase in big data that cannot be controlled so that it is difficult for us to process this data with conventional technology. The increasing amount of data will create new problems in storing and managing data, because the process will become more complex.

It is important for companies to hire a data scientist who has diverse skills because the work of a data scientist is multidisciplinary. Get important insights through Big Data analysis. It is very important for companies that only relevant departments have access to this information. Real-time data can help researchers and companies provide the latest insights for decision making. Getting volume data into a Big Data platform. Companies need to handle large amounts of data every day. The amount and variety of data available today can overwhelm data engineers and it is critical to make data accessibility easy and convenient for company owners and managers. Uncertainty in the data management landscape. With the emergence of Big Data, new technologies and companies, the big challenge faced by companies in Big Data analysis is to know which technology is most suitable for them without any new problems and potential risks. Data storage and quality. Popular data storage options such as data lakes warehouses are generally used to collect and store large amounts of unstructured and structured data in their native format. Missing data, inconsistent data, logic conflicts, and duplicate data all result in data quality challenges. Data security and privacy. Big Data also involves potential risks regarding data privacy and security. Big Data tools are used for analysis and storage using different data sources. This ultimately leads to a high risk of data exposure and makes it vulnerable. Increasing amounts of data also raise privacy and security concerns.
